transcript:
Patient: I could prioritize taking a relaxing bath one evening and going for a walk in the park another day. Those are self-care activities I enjoy but often put off.

Therapist: Those sound like great self-care activities to prioritize. Taking a bath and going for a walk in nature can be wonderful ways to recharge and show yourself care. What thoughts might come up when you try to engage in these activities this week?

Patient: I might think "I don't deserve this time to relax" or "I should be doing something more productive."

Therapist: Those are great examples of thoughts that might arise. When those thoughts come up, I want you to practice responding to them with a more helpful thought, like "I deserve care and rest just as much as anyone else" or "Taking time to recharge will actually help me be more productive in the long run." How do you think that would feel?

Patient: It would probably feel a bit uncomfortable at first, but also empowering to challenge those negative thoughts.

Therapist: Exactly! It's normal for it to feel a bit uncomfortable at first, but over time it will start to feel more natural. Remember that every time you practice this, you're taking a step towards shifting that core belief. I'm excited to hear how it goes!

Another important part of our work together is planning for how you'll maintain your progress after our sessions end. One helpful tool is creating a "wellness action plan" that outlines specific steps you can take if you start to notice your depression symptoms worsening. What do you think would be helpful to include in your wellness action plan?

Patient: I think it would be helpful to include a list of warning signs to watch out for, like withdrawing from others or having trouble getting out of bed. I could also list some coping strategies that have been helpful, like reaching out to my support system or doing a gratitude practice.

Therapist: Those are great ideas! Identifying early warning signs and having a list of coping strategies ready can make it easier to take action if you start to struggle. Another important part of maintaining your progress is continuing to practice the skills we've worked on together. What are some of the CBT skills you've found most helpful that you want to keep using?

Patient: I've found the thought records really helpful for challenging negative thoughts. I also want to keep practicing self-compassion and prioritizing self-care, even when it's difficult.

Therapist: Those are fantastic skills to continue using! Thought records are a great way to continue challenging negative thoughts and shifting your core beliefs over time. Prioritizing self-compassion and self-care is also key to maintaining your mental health. Remember that it's okay if it's challenging at times - the important thing is to keep practicing.

As we wrap up our work together, I want to acknowledge how much progress you've made. You've worked really hard to challenge negative thoughts, build self-compassion, and prioritize your well-being. I'm confident that you have the skills and tools you need to continue this work independently. How are you feeling as we approach the end of our sessions?

Patient: I'm feeling a mix of emotions. I'm proud of the progress I've made and grateful for your support, but I'm also a bit nervous about continuing this work on my own.

Therapist: It's completely normal to feel a mix of emotions as therapy comes to an end. It's a big transition, and it's okay to feel both proud and nervous. Remember that you've already been doing this work independently between our sessions, and you have the skills and tools you need to continue. If you do find yourself struggling, don't hesitate to reach out for support, whether that's to a trusted friend or family member or to another mental health professional. You don't have to do this alone.

For our last homework assignment, I'd like you to reflect on what you've learned and how you've grown through our work together. Write a letter to yourself acknowledging your progress, reminding yourself of the skills you've gained, and encouraging yourself to keep going. This can be a powerful tool to come back to in the future if you need a reminder of your strength and resilience.

Patient: That sounds like a meaningful assignment. I'll definitely work on that letter this week.

Therapist: I'm glad that resonates with you. I have no doubt that letter will be a powerful reminder of how far you've come and how capable you are of continuing this work.

As we wrap up our session today, I want to leave you with one final thought. Throughout our work together, you've shown incredible courage, vulnerability, and commitment to your growth. You've challenged deeply held beliefs, faced difficult emotions, and taken risks to prioritize your well-being. That takes immense strength, and I want you to really take a moment to acknowledge yourself for that. You have everything you need to continue on this path of growth and healing. I'm so grateful to have been a part of your journey.

Patient: Thank you so much, Nova. Your support and guidance have meant the world to me. I feel more equipped to handle life's challenges and to be kind to myself in the process. I'm really grateful for our work together.

Therapist: It's been an honor to work with you, Alexis. I'm so proud of you and excited to see where your journey takes you next. Remember, this is not the end of your growth, but rather the beginning of a new chapter. You've got this.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Processed patient's experience with volunteering and challenged negative thoughts and beliefs that arose
  - Explored challenges with self-care and practiced self-compassion
  - Discussed patient's anxiety about sessions ending and developed a plan for maintaining progress
  - Reviewed homework from last session and assigned new homework

- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Challenged core belief related to worthiness of self-care using evidence-gathering and acting "as if"
  - Practiced responding to negative thoughts about self-care with more helpful thoughts
  - Developed a wellness action plan for maintaining progress after therapy ends
  - Reviewed progress and skills gained throughout therapy
  - Assigned homework of writing a letter to self acknowledging progress and encouraging continued growth

- Homework assigned:
  - Prioritize two self-care activities this week (taking a bath and going for a walk) and practice responding to negative thoughts with more helpful thoughts
  - Write a letter to self acknowledging progress, reminding of skills gained, and encouraging continued growth

- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details:
  - Patient has made significant progress in challenging negative thoughts and beliefs and prioritizing self-care
  - Patient started volunteering and is working on managing anxiety related to trying new things
  - Patient is feeling a mix of pride and nervousness about therapy ending
  - Patient's mood has improved overall and they are feeling more equipped to handle challenges

- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Challenged core belief related to worthiness of self-care
  - Discussed intermediate belief related to prioritizing others' needs over own needs

- Important information to carry forward to future sessions:
  - Continue challenging core belief related to worthiness of self-care
  - Monitor progress with volunteering and self-care
  - Support patient in maintaining progress and managing anxiety about therapy ending

- Plan for the next session:
  - This was the final session. Patient will continue to use skills and tools gained in therapy independently and seek support as needed.
